of months
she told how at first he had brought one

if McKennon was seven instead of 78
there's a chance that his life wouldn't

and his fellow victims MacKinnon
couldn't see Carter and he hadn't even

Carters post-presidency is simply that

especially when it's targeted toward

House President Carter ended up adopting
horrific diseases like guinea worm river
blindness elephantiasis trachoma and
schistosomiasis now I'll bet you haven't
heard of them or if you have I bet you
can't spell them because those are
elements that rarely get much attention
or funding here but they cause

world the victims of these diseases are
among the world's poorest and most

should your average American care about
river blindness or about guinea one or

existed when I was a child in Georgia a
trachoma
malaria
and so forth and the fact that we've

and they are totally unnecessary and
it's almost impossible to imagine the
suffering caused by people with same

1% of the total population of Ethiopia
completely blind but on tiny children
all the way up to the age groups that
have river blindness have itching it's
almost unbearable the people get tired

piece of the wood to scratch themselves
and they scratch all the skin off and
the skin turns it looks like a leopard

blindness well you know it's it's so
heartbreaking to see this happening
unnecessarily and and with the one
treatment of a year of medicines that
are given to us free of charge by
American economy we can make sure that
nobody in this village
will ever go blind so you know the
combination of diseases that afflict

worthwhile and the cost per person is

one of the things he did as president

that we face conditions that frankly
we'd rather not is that is that an apt

the difference is a definition of human
rights in America if you ask somebody on

Rights they'll say freedom of speech for
assembly freedom of worship
followed by jury
you know democratic government but those
are not the human rights that afflict
people in this village well they have
some of those things but but I think
there's a human right to live a decent
life to have a home in which to sleep at
night to be free of preventable diseases
to have a modicum of education to have
some human self-respect some hope that
the future will be better than the past
has been you know those are also human
rights one of the things that's so
important and realizes that these people

their family of values of justice gains

they've just that not have a chance and

chance in life to take advantage of
their own talent in fact gave them look
Jimmy Carter has demonstrated that it is
possible to mount a private war on
